timeline.bodyText: I don't really like the 0.0.1 TBH. I would probably go for 0.1 as the first release
timeline.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Why not use the version of Spring they are based on? That would be far better IMHO.
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText: That's an option as well. We did discuss doing something like 2.1.3.Alpha1, 2.1.3.CR1 etc, but we didn't settle on what the proper strategy should be
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Ah you would base it on Spring Boot. My inclination would have been to really use the Spring version of the related project. That way, you know what you are using.
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText:
But thinking a bit more about it, it has been so long I used Spring that nowadays people might always speak in terms of Spring Boot versions.
I just think that it could be cool to check the version of Spring Security APIs and be able to easily find the related javadoc.
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText:
I'm not saying we need the Spring Boot version, I was just giving an example. I personally think that using the actual Spring component version instead of the Spring Boot version makes more sense as you say.
But then again there is the argument that for Quarkus, the Spring version doesn't really matter, since we don't implement evething anyway, nor are we affected by bugs in Spring projects
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
I don't think that's a good call. They might add some features in new versions and knowing that we don't support them is good IMHO.
We could maybe track the major.minor version only.
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText: That's probably a good compromise
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
Ok, so
<quarkus-spring-api.version>5.1-SNAPSHOT</quarkus-spring-api.version>?
as :
quarkus-spring-*-api --> Spring Boot 2.1.12 --> Spring Framework 5.1.13.RELEASE
replies.author: aureamunoz

replies.bodyText:
@aureamunoz I'm not sure what you mean quarkus-spring-*-api --> Spring Boot 2.1.12 --> Spring Framework 5.1.13.RELEASE.
Let's do <quarkus-spring-web-api.version>5.1.Alpha1</quarkus-spring-web-api.version> for Spring Web 5.1.x.RELEASE. Does that make sense?
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
Yes, that makes sense for me.
I meant that currently the quarkus spring dependencies (quarkus-spring-web-api , quarkus-spring-di-api and so on) depend on Spring Boot 2.1.12.RELEASE which depend on Spring 5.1.13.RELEASE.
replies.author: aureamunoz

replies.bodyText:
Got it, thanks.
I don't think we need to care about the Spring Boot version. The more I think about it the more I agree with @gsmet's proposal of using only the major and minor version of the actual Spring artifact
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Yes, I definitely agree with you. The commit is in progress ;-)
replies.author: aureamunoz

replies.bodyText:
We need to consider that we're likely to make multiple releases that will use the same Spring Boot version.
It's because we only picked a subset of classes from Spring that we need at the moment. If we'll add a new feature to an extension, we might need to include new classes to the dependencies jar.
replies.author: gytis

replies.bodyText: Yes of course. My proposal is that we just add the proper qualifiers: Alpha1, Alpha2, Beta1, Beta2, Final, CR1, CR2 etc.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: I don't think that will work. Let's say you have a Final and you end up needing a new annotation to implement a new feature in Quarkus?
replies.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText: That's what CR1 is supposed to be for.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: I assume we'll have to do similar dependencies bundle for Spring Boot as well (e.g. for spring boot properties extension). Are we going to use spring boot version for that?
replies.author: gytis

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't they be under the io.quarkus groupId?
timeline.author: gsmet

replies.bodyText:
As finally it was decided to hosted under snowdrop github organization I took the same groupId than we have in the snowdrop-bom, it seems confusing to me if we choose io.quarkus for something under snowdrop, no?
For the version I like using the Spring one, yes. WDYT @geoand ?
replies.author: aureamunoz

replies.bodyText:
For me personally it doesn't make a difference. I can go either way. Just keep in mind that if we end up with io.quarkus, @gsmet you'll most likely be the one doing the releases (or grant me access perhaps).
If we end up with snowdrop then we'll be doing the releases and probably grant you access as well.
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: If we got with *.snowdrop group id, it might make sense to have dev.snowdrop instead.
replies.author: gytis

replies.bodyText: I think it would be better to have these modules on the quarkus side. The release process should not be a big burden and we can more easily test future releases and so on. We can grant @geoand (or someone else) the permission to push artifacts on io.quarkus.
replies.author: cescoffier

replies.bodyText: That's fine with me
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: 100% agree
replies.author: gytis

timeline.bodyText:
This is weird.
The dependency should only be in the runtime artifact, shouldn't it?
timeline.author: gsmet

timeline.bodyText: This dependency should only be in the runtime artifact, shouldn't it?
timeline.author: gsmet

timeline.bodyText: Same here, I don't expect to see that one in the deployment artifact.
timeline.author: gsmet
